entry.title: The value of SAP Business Data Cloud for SAP Cloud ERP Private
entry.content:
• SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC) for SAP Cloud ERP Private
  • What is different now? What value and which other new aspects is SAP BDC to our customer?
  • How is the solution positioned?
  • From BW to BDC: what‚Äôs really different
  • Working with Databricks and other partners
  • AI in and with BDC
  • Intelligent applications: what they are and why they matter
  • The business case: value that compounds
  • Commercial packaging: how to get the solution
  • What‚Äôs next?

SAP Business Data Cloud (SAP BDC) for SAP Cloud ERP Private

The Unified Data Foundation for SAP Business Suite and beyond
Enabling Seamless Integration, Analytics & AI-Driven Processes

What is different now? What value and which other new aspects is SAP BDC to our customer?

Bringing AI, data and apps together: How Business Data Cloud supercharges Cloud ERP Private

If there‚Äôs one theme you‚Äôve heard from recent keynotes, it‚Äôs this: the future of enterprise performance lies in bringing AI, data and applications together. When you do, you unlock a flywheel of value. Better data fuels better AI. Better AI augments apps and decisions. Better (configured) apps generate richer data. Round and round it goes, compounding benefit.

Why this matters: three layers that work as one can support a new dimension of productivity and decision support!

Think about the stack in three reinforcing layers:

 

  1. Applications and data sources
  • SAP applications anchor your critical processes and transactional truth.
  • Non-SAP data also matters: external signals, benchmark data, industry specific and market data, documents, logs, time series and more. This includes data sources with structured and unstructured data.
  • Partnerships and integrations with other data bases expand your reach so you can meet the data where it lives.

  1. A harmonized enterprise data foundation
  • Business Data Cloud provides a harmonized semantic layer, delivered in a SaaS application, across all lines of business, applications and applicable to all industries.
  • Prebuilt and curated data products turn raw sources into ready-to-run, semantically consistent building blocks you can trust.
  • The result is a complete enterprise view that supports scenario modeling, planning and cross-process insight without the heavy lifting of manual integration

 

  1. Business AI and modern experiences
  • Agents and assistants like Joule bring an intuitive, conversational layer to analytics and processes.
  • Embedded, real-time insights blend directly into workflows, so users get guidance where decisions happen.
  • Agentic AI will cross systems and processes; it relies on a consistent, governed data foundation, across systems, models and data structures, to be executable and hereby safe and useful.

 

How is the solution positioned?

It is a fact that every customer has a different situation from which they look at this innovation. So everyone needs to be picked up where they come from. When you frame BDC with Cloud ERP Private and AI, it seems best to point out these facts:

  • Considering an end-to-end data lifecycle across SAP and non-SAP is key: SAP customers already have investments in platforms like Databricks, Snowflake and SAP HANA Cloud. Following the idea to unify ingestion, harmonization, governance, enrichment and consumption so analytics, planning and AI all helps everyone to run on consistent ground truth.
  • Debating BW modernization and moving to BDC is worth the time: Many customers are  live with BW on-premise plus a patchwork of analytics. To modernize to a cloud-native, governed data foundation with prebuilt data products, and leave behind the complexity and costs of stitching systems on your own, may help a lot of these organizations and companies.
  • Focusing on adopting intelligent apps: Turn on high-value, out-of-the-box insights and decision support can align to specific line-of-business or industry pain points, and show quick wins that compound over time.

From BW to BDC: what‚Äôs really different

 

BW has been a foundational analytics technology for decades. But BDC is not a one-for-one replacement‚Äîit‚Äôs a bigger step forward because:

  • It‚Äôs SaaS. BDC is delivered as a cloud service. SAP takes responsibility for provisioning, maintaining structures and deploying the data products, so customers can start with usable content rather than building from scratch.
  • It‚Äôs a unified business data fabric. BDC harmonizes data from multiple SAP and non-SAP sources, preserving business context and the underlying data models. That context in particular matters. It enables consistent semantics across systems and allows values to potentially flow back into ERP where appropriate‚Äîan advantage only SAP can deliver at this depth. The data is capable to also serve for a root to understand the sentiment needed for business decisions.
  • It‚Äôs built for agentic AI. Agent networks span processes and systems, and they must rely on a consistent, governed data layer. BDC is where those harmonization rules and transformations live, not just in point-to-point API orchestrations.
  • It extends embedded analytics. The models used in embedded analytics and SAP Analytics Cloud can directly fuel BDC data products. This way, you get continuity of semantics from source to insight.

Working with Databricks and other partners

A common misconception is that opening up to non-SAP platforms means giving up control. The reality is more nuanced:

  • It‚Äôs bi-directional and fair. If Databricks is the customers‚Äô data lakehouse of choice, BDC can read from it‚Äîand Databricks can read from SAP systems governed by your connectivity and security policies.
  • Customers keep their investments. You can bring existing data, models and know-how forward and integrate them into BDC-powered use cases.
  • SAP‚Äôs value is context. What differentiates BDC is its ability to bring data in with full business semantics, align it with SAP data models, and enable value to flow back to ERP processes. No one else can do that as deeply.

AI in and with BDC

AI shows up in multiple ways:

  • AI powered by BDC. With clean, governed, harmonized data products, you can trust the models and agents you deploy. This is where you‚Äôll use Joule, Just Ask in SAP Analytics Cloud, smart functions, embedded insights or fuel any Business AI-enabled processes.
  • AI to build BDC. Within Datasphere, AI and knowledge graph capabilities help optimize data modeling, Apply data science and AI to enrich data products by deriving attributes, harmonizing time series and more. SAP is investing in foundation models tailored for enterprise data contexts to improve derivations and semantics. Agentsmay help in creating analytical artefacts, such as stories. Also Ai is embedded in core analytics functions such as Just Ask, Smart functions ans will be available for generic services, such as summarizations, or the interpretation of results. Finally, Joule is planned as new UI for the analytics environment.

The net: you‚Äôre not just using AI at the ‚Äúlast mile.‚Äù You‚Äôre using it to build a better first mile too.

Intelligent applications: what they are and why they matter

Intelligent applications are not just apps in the narrow sense. Think of them as packaged, outcome-driven solutions composed of:

  • SAP curated data products. Primary and derived data products that harmonize and transform source data, including ready-made KPIs and calculations, where the second layer is a clear gain compared to what was there initially in Datasphere.
  • Domain content. Prebuilt SAP Analytics Cloud stories or other low or no-code assets that deliver immediate analytical value.
  • Applications. Where needed, deeper BTP applications (for example, CAP/RAP) that orchestrate complex decision support across processes.

 

Schematic visualization of Intelligent Applications, Applications, Insights and underlying Data Products, suggested content except marked (e)xtisting or (p)lanned, focus on Cloud ERP Intelligence Private:

Examples:

  • Working Capital Insights. An established SAP Analytics Cloud story, now embedded in the BDC data product concept to help finance teams optimize cash, DSO/DPO and working capital levers.
  • Sustainability Control Tower. A CAP-based application which is getting aligned with BDC data products, bringing ESG and operational data together for visibility and action.

Strategically, SAP is prioritizing industry-focused applications where standardizable decision support exists beyond finance‚Äîareas where uncertainty, external signals and cross-LOB collaboration make a consistent data and AI foundation indispensable. One target will be to create a decision support control center, where it should be possible to pre-evaluate insights showing the as-is situation, and possible reaction scenarios can get generated, developed and finally have a fit in the execution in the underlying systems and their operational processes. Besides this, other pro-code applications with LoB focus are planned.

The business case: value that compounds

Three concrete value pillars typically drive the ROI story:

  • Reduce data engineering effort. Prebuilt, ready-to-run data products can remove up to 80% of the data acquisition and curation effort for many scenarios, especially for customers who previously hand-assembled data pipelines and models around BW.
  • Increase trust and speed with harmonization. Cross-system alignment is costly to build and fragile to maintain in bespoke setups. BDC provides consistent semantics out of the box, so teams can move faster from data to insight to action with fewer errors and reconciliations.
  • Expanded business impact with Insights to Action through intelligent app. Out-of-the-box analytics, planning and decision support reduce time-to-value. Teams get a head start and can tailor from there.

SAP value engineering provides a framework and tooling to quantify total benefits (as a percentage of operating profit and in absolute terms), against costs. Expect modeling around net present value, ROI, payback period and internal rate of return, grounded in customer-specific inputs and scenarios. Happy to discuss in concrete customer interactions.

Of course, there is more value in this setup than to cccelerate analytics or planning, based on delivered Intelligent Applications. In addition, you can make use of SAP Business AI on SAP BDC data, incl. AI Agents/-networks. SAP BDC is the strategic data layer for all SAP Business AI applications, where you can Build own Business AI for the SAP context of your organization, while assuring data consistency, harmonization across SAP Suite products and other API-connected non SAP systems.

Commercial packaging: how to get the solution

At a high level, the packaging aligns the platform and the outcomes:

  • First prerequisite is of course Cloud ERP Private (regular, base or tailored options).
  • Second is the Intelligent application. Cloud ERP Intelligence Private covers access to the intelligent application content itself (data products, domain content, and where applicable, application components).
  • To facilitate the Solution, it is necessary to also have Core BDC capacities linked with it, based on expected size and activity in the system.

 

Be aware that there are also trials available to help teams explore and de-risk.

SAP teams can help shape the right configuration and necessary sizes.

How to get started

  • Pick a high-impact use case. Working capital, sustainability and finance insights are proven entry points. They showcase value quickly and build organizational momentum.
  • Make an inventory of the existing data landscape. Identify SAP and non-SAP sources that matter for the use case. Note where Databricks, Snowflake or other platforms already hold valuable data or models or may add additional value.
  • Assess your BW footprint. If you‚Äôre on BW on-premise, map a modernization path to BDC/ Datasphere. Reuse skills and assets where possible.
  • Pilot with purpose. Use trials and prebuilt content to deliver a credible early win, then scale by extending data products and domain content.
  • Plan for AI enablement. Design for agentic AI from day one by leveraging BDC‚Äôs harmonized semantics. Embed insights where decisions happen, and use Joule and Just Ask to bring analytics to life for users.

What‚Äôs next?

 

The content set is growing:

  • Hundreds of data packages are being delivered and extended across lines of business and industries.
  • More apps and visualizations will arrive with increasing industry depth.
  • The integration of SAP‚Äôs AI assistant and agentic capabilities will deepen across BDC and Cloud ERP Private.

The bottom line

  • This is not old wine in a new bottle. Business Data Cloud with Cloud ERP Private is a new, SaaS-native foundation that unifies data, accelerates trusted insight and enables AI to actually work across the applying enterprise.
  • It‚Äôs unique in its depth of business context. Only SAP can harmonize SAP and non-SAP data with the semantics and process awareness needed to feed insights back into ERP workflows safely and effectively.
  • It meets the customers where they are. Keeping their investments in Databricks, Snowflake and other platforms. Using them alongside BDC to enrich and extend.
  • It‚Äôs outcome-oriented. Intelligent applications give our customers a head start on real decisions, not just dashboards.
  • It‚Äôs measurable. With prebuilt data products reducing engineering effort and intelligent apps accelerating adoption, an organization‚Äôs ROI can be calculated with a clear line to operating performance.

If you‚Äôre ready to turn ‚ÄúAI + data + apps‚Äù from a slogan into a system, start with a use case, lean on BDC‚Äôs prebuilt content, and let the flywheel turn. The sooner to harmonize the data and semantics, the faster analytics, planning and agentic AI will compound value across our customers enterprises and organizations.

entry.title: Re: Error message on MIGO (In BADI)
entry.content:
Which BADI are you using?

If it is MB_MIGO_BADI, then in methods CHECK_ITEM or CHECK_HEADER you can use ET_BAPIRET2 parameter and fill it with error message. See example implementation class CL_EXM_IM_MB_MIGO_BADI.

entry.title: ABAP in ADT ‚Äì Missing Variable Templates and Alternatives?
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I‚Äôm new to SAP and working with ABAP for the first time. I often forget the correct syntax structure, so I find templates very helpful because they prefill certain fields. However, when I press Ctrl+Space in ADT (Version: 2025-09, 4.37.0), I was disappointed to see that there are no options for default variable values or predefined choices for variables.

My questions are:

  • Is there an alternative way to achieve this functionality?
  • Can such functionality be added to Eclipse for ADT?
  • Are there any specific reasons or concerns why templates for variables are not provided by default?

Thanks in advance for your insights.

entry.title: Re: Lift&Shift migration from ERP HCM Payroll to SF ECP
entry.content:
I would highly recommend to customers to use a tool or a partner that uses a tool to manage this configuration migration, such as TIK Nexus Suite. This automates the process and reduces time and risk caused by manual migration/configuration.

I would also add that there is a methodology to migrating from SAP Payroll on-premise to SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll. Moving just configuration is only one step in the methodology of a migration project.

entry.title: Re: Table that holds the text entered in tab Note for a V...
entry.content:
For MM Invoices (MIRO/MIR7), the text you enter in the Notes tab is not stored in a simple header table field. Instead, SAP uses the standard text cluster mechanism:

  • Table: STXH ‚Üí Text header
    Table: STXL ‚Üí Text lines

The key fields are:

TDOBJECT = BELEG (for parked/posted invoices)
TDID = 0001 (for header note, depending on config)
TDNAME = Document number (e.g., the parked invoice number from RBKP-BELNR)
TDSPRAS = Language key

So the note you type in MIR7 is stored as a SAPscript text object, not directly in RBKP or RSEG.

How to retrieve it for workflow is by using function module READ_TEXT with:

ID = '0001' (or whichever text ID is used in your system)
OBJECT = 'BELEG'
NAME = <Invoice Number>
LANGUAGE = <Language>

This will return the text lines entered in the Notes tab. You can then pass those lines into your workflow container for display.

entry.title: Re: 999 ‚Äì The Number of the BSEG
entry.content:
Hello Jack,

yes, the FI validations are performed pretty much at the end of the internal BSEG creation (so-called BSEG projection), so after the FI substitutions and BSEG summarization have taken place.

Ok, if you just want to validate that any functional area has been derived for each document item, you might consider using BAdi AC_DOCUMENT (method CHANGE_AFTER_CHECK) rather than OB28. This very generic BAdi can be used for both substitutions and validations and is based on the generic document item structure ACCIT (rather than on BSEG), where FKBER or FKBER_LONG will always be set, regardless of it being cleared for summarization on BSEG. But yes, right now your scenario works as is, too, since FKBER will not be cleared for summarization üôÇ

Kind regards, 

Stefan

entry.title: Re: Lift&Shift migration from ERP HCM Payroll to SF ECP
entry.content:
@lukemarson Thanks for your comment and for highlighting the value of automated tools and structured methodologies. There is definitely a place for migration accelerators in large or complex projects, and many customers benefit from using partner tools (which are amazing by the way) to streamline configuration transport and reduce manual effort. However, this blog focuses on customers who need to perform a lift-and-shift using only SAP-standard capabilities, often due to project or governance constraints. In these cases, teams still struggle with the practical steps of moving configuration into an ECP landscape, which is why the blog concentrates on that specific scenario.

A full payroll migration methodology absolutely includes much more than configuration transport, data alignment, testing cycles, cutover, and validation are all critical parts of the journey. This blog simply narrows in on the configuration-migration portion, as it is often where teams encounter the most hands-on challenges when third-party tools are not in scope.

Thanks again for sharing your perspective! üëè

entry.title: API for assigning employee to Work Center (IR02/CR02)?
entry.content:
We are looking for a way to programmatically assign employees to work centers, like you do in CR02/IR02.

The only solutions I could find so far appear very risqu√©, making use of low-level HR functions to establish the relationship (for example Use functions to create and link objects in HRP1000 and HRP1001 without PPOME | SAPLSMW.com) but nothing released for customer. Obviously a released, clean API would be first prize.

Even for creating the HRP1001 relationship (which I think is what happens when you create these relationships) there appear to be no released APIs.

What are our options? Has anyone done this successfully and - dare I ask - in a manner that is Clean Core compliant?

entry.title: Re: How do you work with Story reporting and PM Forms ? (and the Guardrails...)
entry.content:
Hi Kris,

I don‚Äôt anticipate any issues with the PM form status report; it‚Äôs usually quite straightforward. Even if you encounter some warnings, I would suggest disregarding them. Just keep the report simple, and it should work fine üòä

However, the 360 form report is a different matter. It tends to run slowly due to the large volume of records‚Äîmany employees, numerous forms and responses, multiplied by 13 questions, plus any additional fields you might include.

To improve performance, I recommend minimising the number of tables and columns in your query and applying as many filters as possible (for example, filtering by period or form status such as ‚Äòcompleted‚Äô). In the designer view, try to limit the number of visuals and avoid mixing dashboards and tables on the same page.

One of the biggest performance challenges I‚Äôve encountered is when a filter is set based on the minimum number of answers, which significantly slows things down. Hopefully, you don‚Äôt have that requirement.

Unfortunately, performance issues with the 360 report are well-known, and there‚Äôs not much we can do to fully resolve them üòè

Kind regards,
Olga

entry.title: Re: no notification mechanism in place for SBN failures
entry.content:
Dear customerÔºå

Greetings from SAP Support.

Intelligent Event Processing (IEP) does not currently allow a user to configure email content or templates, either directly in the Intelligent Event Processing app or in the various use case apps (e.g. Health Monitoring, Integration and Exception Monitoring, Job and Automation Monitoring). 

However, Integration and Exception Monitoring added the ability to collect additional information to be used in Email notifications > Message Details for some categories (e.g. IDoc, PI Messages and Web Services Messages) as per KBA3385352.

Please see updates on Oct 1, 2025 for Operations in What's New in SAP Cloud ALM:
    
* Several apps
    Enhancements to Send Email To and Create Ticket event actions    

Additional details about the service, such as the Service Description and SAP Cloud ALM Tenant, are now included in email notifications and ticket information. These details enable better problem resolution by providing more context about the event.

Best regards,

SAP Support

entry.title: Re: How to Consume SCIM 2.0 API from SAPUI5 Application i...
entry.content:
For standalone SAPUI5 applications, try to leverage the Fiori tools (UI5 tooling) to proxy the call during local development. Try to add a custom middleware configuration to your ui5.yaml file: 

# ui5.yaml
specVersion: '3.0'
metadata:
    name: your_app_name
type: application
framework:
    name: SAPUI5
    version: 1.120.0
    # ... other configurations
server:
    customMiddleware:
        - name: fiori-tools-proxy
          afterMiddleware: compression
          configuration:
              ignorePaths:
                  - /resources
                  - /test-resources
              backend:
                  - path: /scim
                    destination: SCIM_API # Name of the destination in BTP
                    # If using Basic Auth via destination, you typically don't need
                    # user/pwd here, the proxy handles it from BTP configuration.
              # Add a direct proxy for the SCIM API to handle CORS
              # This assumes the base path you want to use is /scim/v2/Users
              # You can also use the backend configuration above, which is cleaner
              # but this is another option if backend fails:
              # - path: /scim/v2
              #   url: https://[SCIM_Service_URL]
              #   destination: SCIM_API
        - name: fiori-tools-appreload
          afterMiddleware: compression
          configuration:
              port: 35729
              path: webapp

after that try to update xs-app.json

{
  "routes": [
    {
      "source": "^/scim/(.*)$",
      "destination": "SCIM_API",
      "target": "$1",
      "authenticationType": "none",
      "csrfProtection": false,
      "cacheControl": "no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate"
    },
    // ... other routes
  ],
  "welcomeFile": "index.html",
  "authenticationMethod": "route"
}


normally this should work because when running locally with the Fiori tools proxy (fiori-tools-proxy middleware), the proxy intercepts the /scim/v2/Users request and forwards it to the actual SCIM API URL using the configuration in ui5.yaml and the credentials stored securely in the BTP destination. This bypasses the browser's CORS restrictions and the direct authentication issues.

entry.title: Prepare building custom pages by using SAP Fiori development portal (5 of 6)
entry.content:
In our previous posts, we explored individual building blocks, their sophisticated capabilities, and how they come together in standard floorplans. We also learned how to extend these standard floorplans when needed. But what happens when your business requirements demand a layout that doesn't match any standard floorplan? The SAP Fiori development portal has you covered. In this post, we'll show you how to build a completely custom page layout while leveraging SAP Fiori elements building blocks to maintain enterprise-grade functionality.

When to Choose Custom Pages

Before we dive into creating custom pages, let's be clear about the decision path. If your UI requirements fit one of the existing standard floorplans (List Report, Object Page, Analytical List Page, Overview Page, or Worklist), you should absolutely use them. Standard floorplans offer:

  • Reduced development and maintenance costs
  • Automatic UI consistency across your application landscape
  • Built-in enterprise features that would take months to develop from scratch
  • Future-proof compatibility with SAP Fiori elements updates

However, when you need a special layout - like a wizard, shopping cart, or any non-standard UI pattern - you're not blocked. You can implement your custom layout while using as many SAP Fiori elements building blocks as possible to retain the benefits of the framework.

Exploring Custom Pages in the Portal

The SAP Fiori development portal's Custom Page  chapter provides comprehensive guidance for building custom layouts. Let's explore its key sections:

  • Overview - Shows a simple custom page demonstrating how building blocks integrate into custom layouts
  • Building Blocks Usage - Explains how to use SAP Fiori elements building blocks in existing UI5 freestyle applications, bridging the gap between traditional UI5 development and the SAP Fiori elements approach
  • Custom Root View - Demonstrates how to create and register custom root views when the standard options (FullScreen and Flexible Column Layout) don't meet your needs
  • Draft Handling - Shows how to leverage the Draft controller extension in your custom pages for seamless draft management

Fiori Development Portal: Custom page sample

These sections provide the foundation for understanding custom page development. Now let's put this knowledge into practice with a real-world example.

Building a Wizard: A Step-by-Step Journey

Let's create a wizard for travel request creation - a floorplan currently not available as a standard in SAP Fiori elements. We'll build this step by step, just as you would when developing your own custom page. The beauty of the portal is that you can experiment with code changes - auto-run is enabled by default, automatically refreshing the preview when you make simple changes. For more complex modifications, you can disable auto-run and manually click the "Run" button to update the sample when you're ready.

Step 1: Setting Up the Wizard Structure

Navigate to the Custom Pages Overview section in the portal. Click "Show Code" to open the code editor. We'll transform this simple page into a wizard.

First, let's add the wizard structure without any content in the steps. Replace the content of the CustomPageSample view with:

<mvc:View
	id="application-product"
	height="100%"
	controllerName="sap.fe.core.fpmExplorer.customPage.CustomPageSample"
	xmlns="sap.m"
	xmlns:mvc="sap.ui.core.mvc"
	xmlns:macros="sap.fe.macros"
>
	<macros:Page title="Create New Travel Request" class="sapUiContentPadding">
		<Wizard
			id="travelWizard"
			enableBranching="false"
			class="sapUiResponsivePadding--header sapUiResponsivePadding--content"
		>
			<WizardStep
				id="travelDataStep"
				title="Travel Information"
				validated="true"
			>
				<!-- We'll add content here -->
			</WizardStep>

			<WizardStep
				id="approvalDataStep"
				title="Budget and Approval"
				validated="true"
			>
				<!-- We'll add content here -->
			</WizardStep>

			<WizardStep
				id="bookingsStep"
				title="Bookings"
				validated="true"
			>
				<!-- We'll add content here -->
			</WizardStep>

			<WizardStep
				id="reviewStep"
				title="Submit Travel Request"
				validated="true"
			>
				<!-- We'll add content here -->
			</WizardStep>
		</Wizard>
	</macros:Page>
</mvc:View>

Now update the controller to support the wizard functionality. In the controller code editor, replace the CustomPageSample controller with:

import PageController from "sap/fe/core/PageController";
import MessageBox from "sap/m/MessageBox";
import type Context from "sap/ui/model/odata/v4/Context";

/**
 * Controller for the custom travel request wizard page.
 */
export default class CustomPageSampleController extends PageController {
	/**
	 * Creates a new travel request draft context and binds it to the view before rendering.
	 */
	public onBeforeRendering(): void {
		const view = this.getView();

		try {
			const model = view.getModel();

			// Create list binding and create a draft context
			const listBinding = model.bindList("/Travel");
			const wizardContext = listBinding.create({
				CurrencyCode_code: "EUR",
				BookingFee: 0,
				TotalPrice: 0,
				TravelStatus_code: "O"
			});

			// Bind the view to the created context
			view.setBindingContext(wizardContext);
			// Set the UI model property to make the forms and table editable
			view.getModel("ui").setProperty("/isEditable", true);
		} catch (error) {
			MessageBox.error("Failed to create travel request: " + (error as Error).message);
		}
	}

	/**
	 * Handler called when the submit button is pressed.
	 */
	public async onSubmitTravelRequest(): Promise<void> {
		// Navigate to the Object Page
		const routing = this.getExtensionAPI().getRouting();
		routing.navigate(this.getView().getBindingContext() as Context);
	}
}

You now have a working wizard structure with four steps! Before rendering the view, the controller's onBeforeRendering() method creates a new draft travel request and binds it to the view, so all our building blocks automatically work with this draft data. The onSubmitTravelRequest() method will be used later to finalize the wizard. For now, notice how the wizard steps are empty but navigable.

Preview wizard without step content

Step 2: Adding the First Form

Now let's add content to our first wizard step. This is where the portal becomes invaluable. You can either navigate to the Form Building Block in the same tab (the portal keeps your changes in memory as long as you don't refresh the browser), or better yet, open the portal in a second browser tab so you can reference the Form documentation while working on your wizard.

Open the Form page in the portal. You'll see it demonstrates the UI.FieldGroup#ApprovalData annotation. But we want to use a different field group for our first step. To see what's available, click "Show Code" next to the annotations example and look at the annotations.cds file in the code editor. You'll find several field groups, including TravelData, which is perfect for our first step.

Back in your wizard code, update the first WizardStep to include the form:

<WizardStep
	id="travelDataStep"
	title="Travel Information"
	validated="true"
>
	<MessageStrip
		text="Please provide the basic information about your travel request."
		type="Information"
		class="sapUiSmallMarginBottom"
	/>
	<macros:Form
		id="travelDataForm"
		metaPath="@UI.FieldGroup#TravelData"
	/>
</WizardStep>

Run the sample and navigate to the first step. You'll see the form with the travel data fields. 

Preview of first wizard step

Notice that the TravelID field appears as the first field. However, since travel IDs are calculated in the backend, it doesn't make sense to show this field here.

Let's remove it from the field group. Go back to the annotations.cds code editor and locate the TravelData field group. Remove the TravelID field:

FieldGroup #TravelData : {
	{ Value : BeginDate },
	{ Value : EndDate },
	{ Value : AgencyID },
	{ Value : CustomerID }
}

Click the "Run" button to refresh the preview with your changes - the TravelID field disappears! This demonstrates the power of annotation-driven UIs: simple metadata changes directly affect the user interface without touching the view code.

Preview without travel ID

Step 3: Adding the Budget & Approval Form

Now let's add the second form. Update the second WizardStep:

<WizardStep
	id="approvalDataStep"
	title="Budget and Approval"
	validated="true"
>
	<MessageStrip
		text="Provide budget information for approval."
		type="Information"
		class="sapUiSmallMarginBottom"
	/>
	<macros:Form
		id="approvalDataForm"
		metaPath="@UI.FieldGroup#ApprovalData"
	/>
</WizardStep>

This step uses the ApprovalData field group, which contains financial information like booking fee and total price. The same building block, configured differently through the metaPath property, delivers completely different content.

Preview second wizard step

Step 4: Adding the Bookings Table

The third step needs a table for managing flight bookings. Navigate to the Table Building Blocks in the portal. Study how the table building block works, paying special attention to the metaPath property.

For our wizard, we want to display bookings that are associated with the travel request. Since our view is bound to a Travel context, we need to set the metaPath to the bookings navigation. Update the third WizardStep:
 

<WizardStep
	id="bookingsStep"
	title="Bookings"
	validated="true"
>
	<VBox>
		<MessageStrip
			text="Add flight bookings for your travel. You can add multiple bookings."
			type="Information"
			class="sapUiSmallMarginBottom"
		/>

		<macros:Table
			id="bookingsTable"
			metaPath="/Travel/to_Booking/@UI.LineItem"
			personalization="Sort,Column"
			header="Flight Bookings"
			creationMode="NewPage"
		/>
	</VBox>
</WizardStep>

Run the sample and navigate to the Bookings step. Click the "Create" button in the table toolbar. You can now create bookings! The table building block automatically provides creation, editing, and deletion capabilities based on the entity's capabilities defined in the service metadata. This is enterprise-grade functionality delivered through a single building block with minimal configuration.

Preview third wizard step

Step 5: Submitting the Travel Request

The final step allows users to review and submit their travel request. Update the fourth WizardStep:

<WizardStep
	id="reviewStep"
	title="Submit Travel Request"
	validated="true"
>
	<VBox class="sapUiContentPadding">
		<Text
			text="You have successfully completed all steps. Your travel request is ready to be submitted."
			class="sapUiMediumMarginBottom"
		/>

		<HBox justifyContent="End" class="sapUiMediumMarginTop">
			<Button
				text="Submit"
				type="Emphasized"
				press="onSubmitTravelRequest"
				icon="sap-icon://paper-plane"
			/>
		</HBox>
	</VBox>
</WizardStep>

 Notice that we're not saving the draft directly using the EditFlow controller extension. Instead, when users click "Submit", the onSubmitTravelRequest method in our controller uses the routing API to navigate to the travel request's Object Page:

public async onSubmitTravelRequest(): Promise<void> {
	// Navigate to the Object Page
	const routing = this.getExtensionAPI().getRouting();
	routing.navigate(this.getView().getBindingContext() as Context);
}

With this approach, users can review their complete travel request in the standard Object Page layout, make any final changes, and then save it using the familiar Object Page header actions. This demonstrates an important principle: you can mix custom pages with standard floorplans in the same application, using each where it fits best.

The Power of Building Blocks in Custom Pages

What we've built demonstrates the core value proposition of SAP Fiori elements building blocks in custom pages:

  • Rapid Development - We created a sophisticated multi-step wizard with forms, tables, and draft handling in minutes, not days
  • Enterprise Features - Each building block brings personalization, validation, error handling, and accessibility automatically
  • Annotation-Driven - Business logic changes (like removing the TravelID field) require only metadata updates, not code changes
  • Consistency - The forms and table in our wizard look and behave exactly like those in standard floorplans, ensuring UI consistency
  • Flexibility - We combined building blocks with standard UI5 controls (Wizard, MessageStrip, Button) to create a layout not available in standard floorplans

Key Takeaways

When building custom pages with SAP Fiori elements:

  • Choose Wisely - Use standard floorplans whenever possible. Resort to custom pages only when your layout requirements genuinely don't fit standard patterns
  • Maximize Building Block Usage - The more you use SAP Fiori elements building blocks in your custom pages, the more enterprise features you get for free
  • Leverage the Portal - Use the SAP Fiori development portal to understand building block capabilities, experiment with configurations, and see immediate results
  • Mix and Match - Combine custom pages with standard floorplans in the same application, using each where appropriate
  • Stay Annotation-Driven - Even in custom pages, let annotations drive as much behavior as possible to minimize code and maximize maintainability

What's Next

In our final post, "Bringing the SAP Fiori development portal and its use to the next level (6 of 6)," we'll explore options to advance portal features and how to best include all project team members for maximizing productivity.

 

To get the full overview about the SAP Fiori development portal, check out the following blog posts of the mini-series:
  • Introducing the SAP Fiori Development Portal: Your Gateway to Rapid SAP Fiori App Creation (1 of 6)
  • Get familiar with SAP Fiori development portal and the power of the building blocks (2 of 6)
  • Explore the potential of SAP Fiori development portal using complex building blocks (3 of 6)
  • Use SAP Fiori development portal to understand extension options for standard floorplans (4 of 6)
  • Prepare building custom pages by using SAP Fiori development portal (5 of 6)
  • Bringing the SAP Fiori development portal and its use to the next level (6 of 6)

entry.title: Fit2Standard Excellence (3/3): From Decision to Delivery - Final Structuring Steps
entry.content:
Co-author:  Oliver-Jens G√∂tz
***

As organizations progress through the Fit2Standard approach, the early phases ‚Äî preparation, system demonstration, analysis, and validation ‚Äî create a shared understanding between central and local teams. By the time these steps are completed, the functional discussions are largely settled, and key questions have been clarified.

The final two phases of the methodology, Review & Approval and Upload & Planning, play an essential role in translating this clarity into a manageable, well-governed delivery plan:

 

 

They are not about re-opening discussions but about organizing what has already been agreed, ensuring that decisions move into implementation in a structured and traceable way.

Review & Approval: Concluding the Decision-Making Process

Review and Approval serve as the formal closure of the analysis and validation work. Its purpose is straightforward: to consolidate findings, confirm decisions, and provide the governance needed before any building activities begin.

The process typically starts with the creation of a clear, focused and easy-understandable decision pack. This includes the validated gaps, their impact assessments, any compliance considerations, and the recommended solutions. Presenting this information in a structured form enables the Product Owner and relevant stakeholders to make well-informed decisions without revisiting previous discussions.

The Product Owner then classifies each item:

  • What will be addressed within the global template
  • What falls out of scope
  • What requires escalation or further review

Where necessary, management approval is most likely required, particularly for items with regulatory or financial implications. The result is an approved decision log ‚Äî a transparent record of what will move forward, on what priority, and under which ownership.

This phase ensures that the project enters delivery with alignment, documentation, and clear governance, avoiding ambiguity or conflicting interpretations in the program.

Upload & Planning: Turning Decisions Into an Actionable Backlog

Once approvals are secured, the next step is to translate decisions into the project‚Äôs operational structure. Upload and Planning focus on transferring requirements into a backlog, preparing the template team for the actual implementation, and organizing the work to ensure that the delivery can begin without delays.

Each approved requirement is transformed into a backlog item (typically into a user story or into a change request), supported by acceptance criteria and relevant attachments. This provides the template team with the context needed to build accurately and efficiently.

During this phase, dependencies are also identified. These can include cross-functional impacts or technical constraints. Pointing these early out allows the project to plan realistically and reduces potential friction during design and build.

A formal handover session typically concludes with the phase. The rollout team presents the backlog to the template delivery team, reviewing business context and supporting materials. This ensures a consistent understanding of the scope and reduces the risk of misinterpretation und unclarity during the implementation.

With this, the program transitions from analysis into execution, supported by a structured plan, a clear set of priorities, and a well-informed delivery team, which is key to successful implementation.

Integration With Earlier Fit2Standard Work

These closing phases do not stand alone; they connect directly to the work already completed:

  • Local System Analysis identified and documented the relevant gaps.
  • Template Validation confirmed their relevance and categorized them.
  • Review & Approval converted these outcomes into final decisions.
  • Upload & Planning operationalized those decisions and prepared them for delivery.

Together, they form a logical and predictable transition from understanding requirements to executing them effectively.

A Structured Conclusion to the Fit2Standard Cycle

Global S/4HANA rollouts benefit most when clarity and governance accompany each phase of Fit2Standard. The Review & Approval and Upload & Planning phases provide this discipline. They ensure that the investment made in analysis and validation results in a well-organized backlog and a focused, transparent delivery plan.

In many organizations, these final steps make the difference between a rollout that proceeds smoothly and one that becomes rather reactive or fragmented. By closing the Fit2Standard cycle with a structured, traceable, and thoughtfully prepared handover to delivery teams, the organizations are enabled with a consistent execution across their subsidiaries and business units.

Related articles: 
‚ÄúA Case Study: Mastering a Complex Rollout at a Utilities Enterprise‚Äù - LINK

‚ÄúFit2Standard Excellence (1/3): Impactful Preparation and Demo‚Äù  - LINK

‚ÄúFit2Standard Excellence (2/3): What Analysis and Validation Really Reveal‚Äù - LINK

‚ÄúFit2Standard Excellence (3/3): From Decision to Delivery ‚Äì Final Structuring Steps‚Äù - LINK

entry.title: Invoking Business Agent Foundation Agents from ABAP: A Step-by-Step Guide
entry.content:
With the rise of intelligent automation and AI-powered solutions in enterprise landscapes, integrating SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) services with on-premise ABAP systems has become increasingly important. In this blog, I'll walk you through the process of invoking agents from the Business Agent Foundation service directly from an ABAP report‚Äîan integration that bridges the gap between traditional SAP systems and modern AI capabilities.

Whether you're looking to enhance your business processes with intelligent agents or simply exploring the possibilities of AI integration in your SAP landscape, this guide will provide you with a comprehensive, hands-on approach to achieve this integration.

 

Pre-requisites: Subaccount in BTP, subscription of Business Agent Framework service in the subaccount, a dedicated client profile with required configurations.

 

Step 1: Create Your Agent in Business Agent Framework

Setting up Business Agent Framework service in your subaccount: Setup - Project Agent Builder Documentation

After setting the service, go to Instances ‚Üí Project Agent Builder ‚Üí Service Keys ‚Üí view. Copy the endpoint url (uaa ‚Üí url) which is required in the OAuth 2.0 Client Profile Configuration.

Start by opening the Business Agent Framework application in your BTP subaccount. Create a test agent and initialize a new chat session. This agent will be the endpoint we'll communicate with from our ABAP system.

 

Note: If you already have a dedicated client profile with required configurations, directly go to "Step 2: Configure the RFC Destination".

 

OAuth 2.0 Client Profile Configuration

Proper authentication is crucial for secure integration. Here's how to set up your OAuth 2.0 client profile:

Part A: Creating the OAuth Client Profile
  1. Navigate to transaction code SE80 (Object Navigator)

  2. Select Development Object and choose your package

  3. Right-click on the package and choose: Create ‚Üí Others ‚Üí OAuth 2.0 Client Profile and enter a meaningful name for your profile


     

  4. Choose 'DEFAULT' as the service provider type

  5. Save your profile

  6. Assign the relevant scopes required for accessing the Business Agent Foundation service



Part B: Configuring the OAuth Client Profile
  1. Start transaction code SOAUTH2_CLIENT (or OA2C_CONFIG for older versions)

    Alternatively, access it via browser:

       https://<host_name>:<https_port>/sap/bc/webdynpro/sap/oa2c_config?sap-language=EN&sap-client=<client>
  2. Click Create and select your previously created client profile

  3. Enter Client Credentials:
    • Navigate to your BTP subaccount
    • Go to: Instances ‚Üí <your_service_instance> ‚Üí Service Keys
    • Copy the Client ID from the service key and enter it in the configuration

  4. Configure Token Endpoint:

    • Under General Settings, enter the token endpoint URL without the `https://` prefix. 
      Use the endpoint url which you copied in the Step 1.

  5. Configure Grant Type:
    • Select 'Client Credentials' as the grant type
    • This is the standard grant type for server-to-server authentication

  6. Verify Scopes:
    • The associated scopes should automatically appear if they were properly configured in Part A

  7. Test the configuration:
    • Save your configuration
    • Navigate to the Token tab
    • Click Request New Token
    • If successful, you'll receive an access token, confirming that your OAuth configuration is working correctly

       

Note: For comprehensive details on OAuth 2.0 configuration in ABAP, refer to the official SAP documentation on [OAuth 2.0 Client for ABAP].

 

Step 2: Configure the RFC Destination

The destination acts as a bridge between your ABAP system and the BTP service. Here's how to set it up:

2.1 Create the HTTP Destination
  1. Navigate to transaction code SM59 in your ABAP system
  2. Create a new RFC destination with the following settings:
    • Connection Type: Select 'G' (HTTP connection to external server)
2.2 Technical Settings
  1. Under the Technical Settings tab enter the host URL of your BTP service without the "https://" prefix

2.3 Authentication Configuration
  1. Navigate to the Logon & Security tab:
    • Under Logon Procedure, select 'Logon with User'
    • Choose 'Basic Authentication' as the authentication method

  2. Click on OAuth Settings:
    • Select your previously configured OAuth client profile (see configuration details in the OAuth Client Configuration step above)

2.4 Test Your Connection
  1. Click on Test Connection to verify connectivity to the host URL
  2. Navigate to the Test OAuth Configuration tab to validate the OAuth setup
  3. If you encounter SSL certificate issues, use transaction code STRUST to upload the required SSL certificate

Note: For more comprehensive information on calling RESTful APIs from ABAP, refer to the [Calling RESTful APIs from SAP ABAP].

 

Step 3: Implement the ABAP Report

Writing the ABAP code to invoke the agent.

3.1 Create Your ABAP Report

Go to transaction code SE38 and create a new report.

3.2 Understanding the CL_HTTP_CLIENT Class

ABAP provides a powerful class called CL_HTTP_CLIENT for making HTTP calls to REST APIs. This class offers two primary methods for creating HTTP client instances:

  • `CREATE_BY_DESTINATION` - Uses a predefined RFC destination
  • `CREATE_BY_URL` - Uses a direct URL

Since we've already created our destination, we'll use `CREATE_BY_DESTINATION`.

3.3 The Complete Code Implementation
A. Create the HTTP Client Object
DATA: lo_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client. cl_http_client=>create_by_destination(
      EXPORTING
          destination = '<Name of the RFC destination>'  
      IMPORTING
          client = lo_http_client " HTTP Client object
      EXCEPTIONS
           argument_not_found = 1
           destination_not_found = 2
           destination_no_authority = 3
           plugin_not_active = 4
           internal_error = 5
           OTHERS = 6
           ).
B. Configure HTTP Method and Version
lo_http_client->request->set_method( if_http_request=>co_request_method_post ).
lo_http_client->request->set_version( if_http_request=>co_protocol_version_1_1 ).

We're using POST method since we're sending data to the agent, and HTTP version 1.1 for compatibility.

C. Set the API Endpoint
lv_url = '/api/v1/Agents(agent_id)/chats(chat_id)/UnifiedAiAgentService.sendMessage'.
CALL METHOD cl_http_utility=>set_request_uri
    EXPORTING
      request = lo_http_client->request
      uri     = lv_url.

Note: Replace `agent_id` and `chat_id` with your actual agent and chat identifiers from Business Agent Framework.

D. Set Content Type
CALL METHOD lo_http_client->request->set_content_type( 'application/json' ).

Since we're sending JSON data, we specify `application/json`. If you were working with XML, you'd use `application/xml` or `text/xml` instead.

E. Prepare and Send the Request Body
lv_string = '{"msg": "give message here", "outputFormat": "Markdown", "async": false, "returnTrace": true}'.
lo_http_client->request->set_cdata( lv_string ).
F. Execute the Request
CALL METHOD lo_http_client->send
    EXCEPTIONS
      http_communication_failure = 1
      http_invalid_state         = 2.

CALL METHOD lo_http_client->receive
    EXCEPTIONS
      http_communication_failure = 1
      http_invalid_state         = 2
      http_processing_failed     = 3.

These two calls handle the request-response cycle.

G. Process the Response
CALL METHOD lo_http_client->response->get_status
    IMPORTING
      code   = http_status
      reason = reason.

  response = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).
H. Extract the Agent's Response
SPLIT response AT '"response":"' INTO rest response.
SPLIT response AT '","' INTO explanation rest.

This parsing logic extracts the actual response text from the JSON structure. The variable `explanation` now contains the agent's reply.

 

 

In conclusion, integrating SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) services with on-premise ABAP systems is a powerful way to leverage modern AI capabilities within your traditional SAP landscape. By following the step-by-step guide provided in this blog, you can successfully invoke agents from the Business Agent Foundation service directly from an ABAP report. This integration not only enhances your business processes with intelligent automation but also demonstrates the flexibility and extensibility of SAP systems.

entry.title: Re: Vendor Automatically Changes to Head Office Vendor Du...
entry.content:
Why the vendor is getting replaced during invoice posting is because of the following:

  • If the branch vendor‚Äôs company code data has the ‚ÄúAlways use alternative payee‚Äù flag set, the system will substitute the vendor at document level during invoice entry, not only during payment. This leads to invoice posting to the HO vendor, which breaks GST reporting and vendor aging.
  • If ‚ÄúPayee in document‚Äù is used (either by default or via partner determination), the system can replace the vendor on the FI document during MIRO/Invoice apps.
  • If the supplier partner determination is set to default the HO as the Invoicing Party (PI) for FI documents, posting may shift to HO instead of the branch vendor, depending on the posting logic in public cloud.
  • If the PO has a partner function set (e.g., PI = HO), MIRO can inherit that and switch the vendor. You mentioned the PO vendor is correct; still verify PI isn‚Äôt defaulting to HO.

Perform the below steps to fix the issue

  • In BP Company Code Data Payment transactions tab, check ‚ÄúAlternative payee‚Äù is populated with HO. Ensure the checkbox/indicator equivalent to ‚ÄúAlways use alternative payee‚Äù is NOT set.
  • Also check there is no default ‚ÄúPayee in document‚Äù referencing HO. Prevents vendor substitution during invoice posting.
  • Check the partner schema assigned to the supplier account group does not default PI (Invoicing Party) or any payee mapping to the HO for FI documents. If PI is required in procurement, ensure it doesn‚Äôt drive FI vendor replacement at MIRO.
  • Check the account group used for branch vendors does not enforce a payee/partner override that affects FI documents. Confirm field statuses do not force ‚ÄúPayee in document‚Äù or ‚ÄúAlways use alt payee.‚Äù
  • Check PI partner is not HO unless you explicitly need it for ordering; avoid PI mapping that bleeds into MIRO vendor substitution.

Below would be the recommended SAP setup for multi-GST vendor with HO payment

One BP per GSTIN (branch vendor): Post all invoices to the branch vendor. Maintain GST registration and tax settings per state.

HO as alternative payee only: Maintain HO in the branch vendor‚Äôs company code data as alternative payee, but do not set ‚ÄúAlways use alternative payee‚Äù or any configuration that replaces vendor in the document.

Partner functions: Use PI, OA, LF, etc., carefully. Do not default HO as PI in a way that affects FI postings.

APP run: Let payment redirection happen via alternative payee at payment time; vendor line items and aging stay with the branch vendor.

This aligns with the GST design and avoids non-compliance and reconciliation issues

entry.title: Implementing Event-Driven Architecture in CAP Java using SAP Event Mesh
entry.content:
1. Why Event-Driven Architecture on BTP

Traditional request-response patterns tightly couple services and increase latency.
Event-driven architecture improves application design by enabling:

  • Asynchronous communication between microservices

  • Decoupled integration between S/4HANA, BTP services, and custom apps

  • Real-time notifications and process automation

  • Better scalability and resilience

SAP Event Mesh acts as a fully managed messaging backbone on SAP BTP, supporting queue and topic-based messaging using AMQP and REST APIs.

2. Architecture Overview

The scenario covered in this blog:

  1. A CAP Java service publishes an event (e.g., new SupplierQuotation created).

  2. SAP Event Mesh receives the event and delivers it to a queue.

  3. Another CAP Java service or an external microservice consumes the event asynchronously.

This keeps the producing and consuming services independent and scalable.

3. Prerequisites

  • SAP BTP Cloud Foundry subaccount

  • SAP Event Mesh service instance

  • CAP Java project (Spring Boot or Node.js runtime)

  • Basic knowledge of OData services in CAP

  • A messaging queue and topic configured in Event Mesh

4. Configure Event Mesh in MTA

Add the Event Mesh service to your mta.yaml:

- name: event-mesh
  type: org.cloudfoundry.managed-service
  parameters:
    service: enterprise-messaging
    service-plan: default

Bind it to your CAP Java application:

requires:
  - name: event-mesh
    parameters:
      config:
        rules:
          - topic: sap/demo/quotation
            publish: true
            subscribe: true

 

Deploy using: 

mbt build -t mta && cf deploy mta_archives/app.mtar

5. Event Mesh Credentials in CAP Java

After deployment, the CAP runtime automatically reads the bound service credentials from VCAP_SERVICES.

These values include:

  • Broker URL

  • Client ID and Client Secret

  • Token endpoint

  • Messaging namespace

CAP Java uses the SAP Cloud SDK under the hood for Event Mesh connectivity.

6. Publishing Events from CAP Java

Let us assume we have an entity:

@Entity
public class SupplierQuotation {
    
    public String ID;
    public String supplierId;
    public BigDecimal amount;
}

 

To publish a message after creation, use a custom event handler:

@Component
public class SupplierQuotationHandler implements EventHandler {

    (event = CdsService.EVENT_CREATE, entity = "my.srv.SupplierQuotations")
    public void onCreate(SupplierQuotation quotation) {

        Map<String, Object> payload = Map.of(
                "quotationId", quotation.ID,
                "supplierId", quotation.supplierId,
                "amount", quotation.amount
        );

        sendEvent("sap/demo/quotation", payload);
    }

    private void sendEvent(String topic, Object payload) {
        MessagingService messaging = MessagingServiceProvider.getMessagingService();
        messaging.emitEvent(topic, payload);
    }
}

The MessagingService abstracts low-level connectivity and sends messages to Event Mesh using the REST interface.

7. Consuming Messages in CAP Java

To consume messages, bind the queue to the topic inside Event Mesh:

  • Topic: sap/demo/quotation

  • Queue: quotation-queue

  • Rule: subscribe to this topic

Then create a message listener:

@Component
public class QuotationMessageConsumer {

    @MessagingDestination("quotation-queue")
    public void onMessage(String message) {
        System.out.println("Received message: " + message);

        // process message
        // store into log table, trigger workflow, etc.
    }
}

This is a Spring-like annotation provided by the CAP messaging framework, automatically subscribing the service to the queue.

8. Error Handling and Retries

Event Mesh supports:

  • Automatic redelivery

  • Dead Letter Queues (DLQ)

  • Message TTL and backoff policies

In CAP Java you can implement structured error handling:

try {
    processMessage(message);
} catch (Exception ex) {
    throw new MessagingException("Processing failed", ex);
}

Throwing an exception ensures the message is returned to the queue and retried.

9. Securing Events with OAuth

Event Mesh uses OAuth for all publish and subscribe operations.

Key points:

  • Always use the XSUAA token from service binding (Refer to my blog for more details)

  • Ensure your app has messaging.publish or messaging.consume scope

  • Use minimal scopes for principle of least privilege

CAP Java automatically injects OAuth tokens when emitting or consuming events.

10. Best Practices for Event-Driven CAP Applications

  • Use clear topic naming standards:
    sap/<domain>/<subdomain>/<eventName>/v1

  • Avoid large payloads; store details in database, send only IDs

  • Keep consumers idempotent

  • Implement correlation IDs for debugging

  • Enable DLQ and retry policies for reliability

  • Do not block listener threads with long-running processing

  • Maintain versioned event schemas

11. Testing the Setup

You can test publishing manually using:

cf logs <app-name>

Or by sending a message from Event Mesh Dashboard:

  • Navigate to ‚ÄúQueues‚Äù

  • Choose your queue

  • Select ‚ÄúSend Test Message‚Äù

Verify that your consumer receives the message.

12. Final Thoughts

Event-driven architecture brings flexibility, decoupling, and real-time capabilities to modern business applications. By combining CAP Java with SAP Event Mesh, developers can implement scalable asynchronous workflows without tightly coupling services.

Using Event Mesh topics and queues allows CAP applications to communicate reliably, handle spikes in load, and integrate with S/4HANA or other BTP services through lightweight events. CAP Java simplifies this further by providing built-in messaging abstractions, allowing you to focus on business logic rather than low-level infrastructure.

Whether you are building microservices, automating procurement processes, or reacting to business events as they happen, this architecture provides a robust foundation for enterprise-grade applications on SAP BTP.

entry.title: SHORT DUMPÔºöOBJECTS_OBJREF_NOT_ASSIGNED_NO
entry.content:
Hi All,

I know this runtime error has been discussed by many people. However, none of the solutions applied to my problem.

My system contains a custom report that uses an Excel template on OAOR to input data and then exports it as an Excel macro file.
An error occurs every time data is inserted into an Excel cell using the following statement, instead of an error occurring in each cell.

DEFINE cell_cls.  
  IF &3 IS NOT INITIAL.

*  translate &3 to upper case.
  FREE: gt_ranges, gt_input.
  CALL METHOD r_excel->insert_range_dim
    EXPORTING
      name     = 'cell'
      no_flush = 'X'
      top      = &1
      left     = &2
      rows     = 1
      columns  = 1
    IMPORTING
      error    = r_error.

  gs_ranges-name = 'cell'.
  gs_ranges-columns = &2.
  gs_ranges-rows = &1.
  APPEND gs_ranges TO gt_ranges .
  CLEAR gs_ranges .

  gs_input-column = 1.
  gs_input-row = 1.
  gs_input-value = &3.
  APPEND gs_input TO gt_input .
  CLEAR gs_input .

  CALL METHOD r_excel->set_ranges_data
    EXPORTING
      ranges   = gt_ranges
      contents = gt_input
      no_flush = 'X'
    IMPORTING
      error    = r_error.

  ENDIF.

END-OF-DEFINITION.

The problem doesn't occur every time it's run; it only happens to some users, and it's intermittent.

But I am absolutely certain that there was data when I filled in the storage cell.

In fact, this problem occurs in two reports, with one of them even reporting an error because ADRC-NAME1 is missing, which should be impossible.

Can someone provide any possible reasons for the problem?

English is not my usual language, so please ask any questions if anything is unclear.

Thank you all for your assistance!

entry.title: Re: What is SAP Analytics Cloud preview tenant?
entry.content: This resource includes details about the Preview. It includes a PPT and a video presentation https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-analytics-cloud-landscape-architecture-amp-life-cycle-management/ba-p/13446849
